issues.description: The problem statement instructs students to access the children field directly via a public field (person.children). However, both the template and the solution define children as a private field with public getter/setter (private Set<Person> children; public Set<Person> getChildren()). This visibility mismatch will confuse students (they may try to access a nonexistent public field) and contradicts the provided code structure.
issues.suggested_fix: Either update the problem statement to instruct students to use the getter (person.getChildren()) and/or the setter (person.setChildren(...)) consistently with the provided code, or change the Person class in the template to expose a public children field if the exercise intentionally requires direct field access. The less intrusive fix is to correct the problem statement to reference person.getChildren().

issues.description: The problem statement refers to the 'children list' (implying a List type), while the template and solution declare children as a Set (private Set<Person> children). This mismatch in the described collection type may cause minor confusion about the expected collection semantics (ordering, duplicates) and available operations.
issues.suggested_fix: Clarify the problem statement to use neutral/accurate terminology such as 'children collection' or explicitly state 'Set<Person>' (or change the model to use List<Person> if ordered/duplicate semantics are required). The recommended fix is to update the wording in the problem statement to match the template (Set<Person>) and to instruct use of the getter (person.getChildren()).

issues.description: The problem statement instructs students to access the children list directly via the public field notation person.children, but both the template and the solution declare the children attribute as a private field with a getter (getChildren()). This mismatch between the expected access pattern in the problem text and the actual code will confuse students (they may try to access person.children and get a compile/error or be uncertain whether to use the getter).
issues.suggested_fix: Align the problem statement with the code.
